articles.headline: Chip Credit Cards Give Retailers Another Grievance Against Banks
articles.snippet: A battle between retailers and the banking industry over credit card technology adds fuel to a feud over what merchants pay for the processing of credit and debit transactions.
articles.abstract: A battle between retailers and the banking industry over credit card technology adds fuel to a feud over what merchants pay for the processing of credit and debit transactions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The employee perched on a stepstool by the checkout at Trader Joe’s in Union Square in Manhattan is like an air traffic controller: Register 6 for one customer. Register 9 for the next.

articles.headline: Japan’s Economy Feels the Sting of China’s Slowdown
articles.snippet: Dependent on Chinese orders that are dwindling, Japan’s heavy-industry manufacturers are slumping, along with the rest of the Japanese economy.
articles.abstract: Dependent on Chinese orders that are dwindling, Japan’s heavy-industry manufacturers are slumping, along with the rest of the Japanese economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In its small way, Tsutomu Nyuwa’s metalworking shop in Yasugi, Japan, has been feeding the economic boom 700 miles away in China.

articles.headline: After Paris Attacks, C.I.A. Director Rekindles Debate Over Surveillance
articles.snippet: The director, John O. Brennan, criticized “hand-wringing” over spying by governments and said that restrictions on surveillance made it harder to find terrorists.
articles.abstract: The director, John O. Brennan, criticized “hand-wringing” over spying by governments and said that restrictions on surveillance made it harder to find terrorists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A diabolical range of recent attacks claimed by the Islamic State — a Russian airliner blown up in Egypt, a double suicide bombing in Beirut and Friday’s ghastly assaults on Paris — has rekindled a debate over the proper limits of government surveillance in an age of terrorist mayhem.

articles.headline: After Paris Attacks, a Darker Mood Toward Islam Emerges in France
articles.snippet: Unlike after the Charlie Hebdo attacks in January, calls for solidarity with Muslims have been rare while even the left-wing government considers harsher security measures.
articles.abstract: Unlike after the Charlie Hebdo attacks in January, calls for solidarity with Muslims have been rare while even the left-wing government considers harsher security measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — November is not January. That thought has been filtering through the statements of most French politicians and the news media, and most people seem to understand.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: The Hidden Costs of Terrorism
articles.snippet: The attack in Paris could have far-reaching implications for the future of the eurozone and for companies doing business there.
articles.abstract: The attack in Paris could have far-reaching implications for the future of the eurozone and for companies doing business there.
articles.lead_paragraph: What is the economic cost of terrorism?

articles.headline: G.O.P. Governors Vow to Close Doors to Syrian Refugees
articles.snippet: Twenty-five governors pledged to block the refugees from entering their states, because the terrorists who attacked Paris last week included a man who had entered Europe with a Syrian passport.
articles.abstract: Twenty-five governors pledged to block the refugees from entering their states, because the terrorists who attacked Paris last week included a man who had entered Europe with a Syrian passport.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republican fury over illegal immigration and border security took on a new dimension Monday as a growing number of governors, presidential candidates and members of Congress rushed to oppose or even defy President Obama’s plan to resettle 10,000 Syrian refugees.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: In Suspects’ Brussels Neighborhood, a History of Petty Crimes and Missed Chances
articles.snippet: Molenbeek, a known haven for extremists, was home to Ibrahim Abdeslam, who blew himself up in Paris. Although the authorities there had him in their sights, he slipped through their fingers.
articles.abstract: Molenbeek, a known haven for extremists, was home to Ibrahim Abdeslam, who blew himself up in Paris. Although the authorities there had him in their sights, he slipped through their fingers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Just eight days before Ibrahim Abdeslam blew himself up in Paris as part of an elaborate terrorist operation that killed 129 people on Friday, the authorities in the heavily immigrant Brussels district of Molenbeek already had the future terrorist in their sights.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins, Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: With Modigliani Purchase, Chinese Billionaire Dreams of Bigger Canvas
articles.snippet: The couple who bought the Modigliani at a Christie’s auction last week said they hoped to transform their museum in Shanghai into a world-class destination.
articles.abstract: The couple who bought the Modigliani at a Christie’s auction last week said they hoped to transform their museum in Shanghai into a world-class destination.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Even as the cost of his quarry pulled away from the $100 million mark, Liu Yiqian remained calm.

articles.headline: Heavy Gunfire Erupts as French Police Seek Suspects in Raid
articles.snippet: The police stormed the northern Paris suburb of St.-Denis early Wednesday morning in a raid evidently aimed at capturing at least two fugitives.
articles.abstract: The police stormed the northern Paris suburb of St.-Denis early Wednesday morning in a raid evidently aimed at capturing at least two fugitives.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The police stormed the northern Paris suburb of St.-Denis before dawn Wednesday morning in a raid aimed at capturing at least two fugitives suspected in the terrorist attacks that killed 129 people in Paris on Friday.
articles.byline: By Aurelien Breeden, Liz Alderman and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Russia Allies With France Against ISIS, Saying Jet That Crashed in Sinai Was Bombed
articles.snippet: After acknowledging for the first time that a bomb brought down a Russian jet, Moscow said it was coordinating with France in ramping up attacks on Syrian territory.
articles.abstract: After acknowledging for the first time that a bomb brought down a Russian jet, Moscow said it was coordinating with France in ramping up attacks on Syrian territory.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia on Tuesday said that it was coordinating with the French military in sharply ratcheting up attacks on Syrian territory, especially areas held by the Islamic State, as the government for the first time acknowledged that a bomb had destroyed a Russian charter jet  that crashed more than two weeks ago in Egypt.

articles.headline: Recent Setbacks Cast Harsh Light on Cyrus Vance, the Manhattan Prosecutor
articles.snippet: Recent defeats have led to second-guessing among lawyers about whether the Manhattan district attorney’s office has made financial trials overly complex.
articles.abstract: Recent defeats have led to second-guessing among lawyers about whether the Manhattan district attorney’s office has made financial trials overly complex.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the district attorney of Manhattan, Cyrus R. Vance Jr. enjoys the spotlight of being a top prosecutor in the nation’s financial capital.

articles.headline: Microsoft Sheds Reputation as an Easy Mark for Hackers
articles.snippet: As episodes of online hacking have become even more startling, the company has been evolving to confront security threats and improve how information is shared.
articles.abstract: As episodes of online hacking have become even more startling, the company has been evolving to confront security threats and improve how information is shared.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — Microsoft was once the epitome of everything wrong with security in technology. Its products were so infested with vulnerabilities that the company’s co-founder, Bill Gates, once ordered all of Microsoft engineers to stop writing new code for a month and focus on fixing the bugs in software they had already built.

articles.headline: Strong Sales at Walmart, Home Depot and TJX
articles.snippet: Sales and traffic improved at Walmart stores in the United States, but operating income fell more than 8 percent as the retailer invested in online operations and its work force.
articles.abstract: Sales and traffic improved at Walmart stores in the United States, but operating income fell more than 8 percent as the retailer invested in online operations and its work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robust sales numbers from Walmart, Home Depot and TJX on Tuesday are helping to ease concerns over the American consumer’s health in the countdown to the Black Friday sales.
